summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) personnel discussing the handling of Touhy requests for documents related to Jeffrey Epstein from a victim involved in civil litigation against his estate. It includes internal deliberations about disclosing a grand jury subpoena and drafting a formal response to the victim's counsel, Robbie Kaplan.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney representing a victim/plaintiff in a civil suit against Epstein's estate, to whom the US Attorney's Office is preparing to send a formal Touhy response letter.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the criminal investigation; the subject of the document requests from a victim involved in civil litigation against his estate.

connections.description: Kaplan represents a plaintiff (victim) in a civil lawsuit against Epstein's estate, seeking information from the government's investigation.

events.title: Coordination on Touhy Request Handling
events.description: Internal discussion to establish a point person for handling Touhy requests from Epstein civil plaintiffs and to coordinate with criminal AUSAs.

events.title: Preparation of Document Production
events.description: AUSA attaches a draft response letter and documents for production in response to a victim's Touhy request related to Epstein.

events.title: Approval for Grand Jury Subpoena Disclosure
events.description: Internal approval given to disclose a previously disclosed grand jury subpoena to a victim (Jane Doe) as part of the Touhy request response.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was processing Touhy requests from victims involved in civil litigation against Jeffrey Epstein's estate.
A specific victim (referred to as Jane Doe in the chain) was seeking documents, and the office approved disclosing a grand jury subpoena to her as it had been previously disclosed.
Robbie Kaplan of Kaplan Hecker & Fink LLP was identified as counsel for the plaintiff/victim making the request.
The correspondence reveals internal procedural coordination between civil and criminal divisions within the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding Epstein-related information.
The document includes detailed boilerplate language explaining the Touhy regulations governing disclosure of government information in third-party litigation.
